Dear Ms. Shenberger:
Attached is the Interim Report for the above referenced facility completed on July 8-15,
2021. Due to the violations of applicable licensing rules, sections of the contract and
Modified Implementation, Sustainability and Exit Plan (MISEP) requirements, a written
corrective action plan is required. It should be noted that violations of any licensing rules
are also violations of the MISEP and your contract. The corrective action plan is due 15
days from the date of this letter and must include the following:
 How compliance with each citation will be achieved.
 Who is directly responsible for implementing the corrective action for each
licensing statute and rule or section of the contract or MISEP citation.
 Specific time frames for each citation as to when the correction will be
completed or implemented.
 How continuing compliance will be maintained once compliance is
achieved.
 For repeat violations, explain why the previous CAP was unsuccessful.
 The signature of the responsible party and a date.
If you fail to submit an acceptable corrective action plan, disciplinary action may result.

III. DESCRIPTION OF FINDINGS
1.) The facility is in compliance with all applicable licensing statutes and rules except
for the following:
R 400.12306 Application request.
(4) An agency shall document that the licensee has been given
an application for renewal of the license not less than 60
calendar days before the expiration date of the license.
In one out of eight certification records reviewed, the licensee was not given an
application for renewal of the license not less than 60 calendar days before the
expiration date of the license. The application was given on December 14, 2020, and
the license expired on February 5, 2021.
R 400.12310 Initial evaluation.
(6) An agency shall inform the applicant that a copy of the initial
evaluation is available upon request.
In three out of eight certification records reviewed, there was no documentation that
the agency informed the applicants that a copy of the initial evaluation is available
upon request.
R 400.12311 Foster parent/agency agreement.
(3) An agency shall document review of the foster
parent/agency agreement with the foster family at least annually
and, when needed, develop a new agreement.
In two out of eight certification records reviewed, the foster parent/agency
agreement was not reviewed in 2020.
R 400.12319 Substitute care policy.
An agency’s substitute care policy shall, at a minimum, contain
provisions for all of the following: (a) Qualifications for substitute
caregivers, consistent with the requirements of 1973 PA 116
and child care licensing rules.
4

In one out of eight certification records reviewed, there was no documentation that a
central registry clearance was completed for the foster parent’s substitute caregiver.
REPEAT VIOLATION ESTABLISHED — 2020 Renewal Inspection, CAP approved
June 25, 2020.
R 400.12324 Reevaluation.
(8) An agency shall complete a reevaluation and shall make a
licensing recommendation to the department at least 15
calendar days before the expiration date of the foster home
license.
In two out of eight certification records reviewed, the agency did not complete a
reevaluation and make a licensing recommendation to the department at least 15
calendar days before the expiration date of the foster home license.
 For one record, the agency made a recommendation to DCWL on January
29, 2021, and the license expired on February 9, 2021.
 For one record, the agency made a recommendation to DCWL on January
29, 2021, and the license expired on February 5, 2021.
R 400.12326 Borrowed home.
(1) Before placing a child in a foster home certified by another
agency or tribe, the agency shall have a record containing all of
the following documents:
(a) Prior approval from the certifying agency authorizing the
placement of a child in the home.
(c) A copy of the initial evaluation with written endorsement
by the borrowing agency that the evaluation is acceptable.
(e) A list of all children currently placed in the home.
(h) A copy of the current children’s foster home license
application and children’s foster home licensing transaction
record documents from the certifying agency.
(i) A copy of all special evaluations completed during the last
2 years.
5

(1)(a) In one out of three borrowed home records reviewed, prior approval from the
certifying agency authorizing the placement of a child in the home was not received
prior to the effective date of the borrowed bed agreement. The borrowed bed
agreement began on November 25, 2020, and the certifying agency gave approval
of the placement on November 30, 2020.
(1)(c) In one out of three borrowed home records reviewed, there was no
documentation of the agency’s written endorsement that the initial evaluation is
acceptable.
(1)(e) In one out of three borrowed home records reviewed, there was not a list of all
children currently placed in the home.
(1)(h) In two out of three borrowed home records reviewed, a copy of the current
children’s foster home license application was not in the record.
(1)(i) In one out of three borrowed home records, which had special evaluations, the
January 20, 2021, special evaluation was not in the record when it was reviewed.
REPEAT VIOLATION ESTABLISHED for (1)(a) and (1)(c), — 2020 Renewal

(6) An agency shall do all of the following:
(c) Provide a copy of the report to any social services worker

R 400.12413 Medical and dental care policy.
(1) An agency’s medical and dental care policy shall, at a
minimum, include all of the following:
(c) A physical examination for each child as follows, unless a
greater frequency is medically indicated:
(ii) For a child 2 years of age or older, a physical

placement or a new physical examination shall be completed
within 30 calendar days after placement.
(f) The provision of a dental examination and any treatment
required for each child who is 4 years of age and older,
including both of the following:

(i) A dental examination within 12 months before

more than 90 calendar days after placement.
(1)(c)(ii) In one out of eight foster children’s records reviewed, the foster child’s initial

January 25, 2021.
R 400.12417 Foster parent information.
(1) An agency shall provide a foster parent with all of the
following information before the placement or replacement of a
child:
(a) Child’s name.
(b) Child’s date of birth.
(c) Available known information about the child’s health.
(d) Any known history of abuse or neglect of the child.
(e) All known emotional and psychological factors relating
to the care of the child.
(f) All known behaviors of the child.
(g) Circumstances necessitating placement or replacement
of the child.
(h) Any other known information to enable the foster parent
to provide a stable, safe, and healthy environment for the foster
child and the foster family, including information about siblings
who do not reside in the foster home.
(i) Name of assigned social service worker.
(j) Authorization to provide routine and emergency medical
care.
(1)(a-j) In one out of eight foster children’s records reviewed, the foster parent was
not provided with the information specified in the rule prior to or at the time of
placement. The foster child was placed in the foster home on November 2, 2020,
and the foster parent was provided the information specified in the rule on November
17, 2020.
R 400.12418 Development of service plans.
(2) An agency shall complete written service plans for each child
and parent or parents, as follows:
(b) Within 120 calendar days after the initial removal and at

PA 116.722.112a Child caring institution, foster family home, foster family

DHHS Policy Placement Exception Requests and Approvals.

A placement exception request (PER) must be completed if
placement will result in any of the following:
 More than three foster children in the foster home or
relative caregiver's home.
 More than five total children, including the foster family or
relative caregiver's biological and/or adopted children.

in the foster home or relative caregiver's home.

PAFC-Supervised Cases in All Other Counties

DHHS Policy Family Team Meetings: Types and Timeframes.
FOM 722-06B
The following events shall trigger FTM for out of home cases:
 Case Plan Development/ Reassessment: Initial Case
Plan (ISP) - within 30 calendar days before the case plan
due date. Note: This FTM may be combined with the
CPS Case Opening (ISP) FTM.
 Case Plan Development/ Reassessment: Updated Case
Plan (USP) - within 30 calendar days before the case
plan due date. Permanent Ward Service Plan (PWSP) -
within 30 calendar days before the case plan due date.
 Semi-Annual Transition Meeting - within 30 calendar
days after the youth’s 14th birthday and every six months
thereafter. For youth entering out-of-home placement at
age 14 or older, the semi-annual transition meeting must
be held within 30 calendar days of the removal date.
Documentation The DHS-1105, Family Team Meeting (FTM)
Report, must be completed for every FTM.

DHHS Policy Timely Entry of Case Contacts.
FOM 722-06H
All caseworker contacts must be entered in MiSACWIS; this

pertinent information obtained must be summarized and
included in the appropriate section of the case service plan. All
face-to-face contacts must be entered in MiSACWIS, within five

 Any face-to-face contacts with children, parents, or
caregivers made by any of the following:
• Foster care worker.
• Parent/child face-to-face contacts.
• Sibling/child face-to face contacts.

DHHS Policy Caseworker Contact with Parent(s)/Guardian(s).
FOM 722-06H
For each child with a permanency goal of reunification, the
child’s assigned caseworker must have face-to face contact with
the child’s parent/guardian as follows:
First Month after Initial Out-of-Home Placement
The caseworker must have at least two face-to-face contacts
with each parent/guardian, at least one of which must occur in
the parent’s residence. One of the face-to-face contacts must be
used to discuss the following:
 Petition and court orders.
 Case service plan.
 Family Assessment of Needs and Strengths.
 Child Assessment of Needs and Strengths.
 Parent-Agency Treatment Plan & Service Agreement.
 Scheduling and expectations of parenting time.
Subsequent Months
The caseworker must have face-to-face contact with each
parent/guardian at least once each calendar month, with at least
one contact in each quarter occurring in the parent’s place of
residence.
In one out of eight foster children’s records reviewed, for the subsequent months,
the caseworker did not have face-to-face contact with each parent/guardian at least
once each calendar month. There were no face-to-face visits or contact with the birth
mother in October 2020 and in June 2021.

DHHS Policy Medical Passports.
FOM 801
For children first entering foster care, the initial medical passport
must be provided to the foster care provider within two weeks of
the child's placement date. The actual date the foster care
provider receives the medical passport must be documented in
MiSACWIS.
All medical information within the medical passport must be
current and updated at least quarterly to reflect the child's
current and complete health information.
Each foster care caseworker who transfers a child's medical
passport to another caseworker must sign and date the medical
passport verifying that s/he has sought and obtained the
necessary information under law and MDHHS policy.
An updated medical passport is provided to:
 Legal parents, if the child is a temporary court ward.
--Quarterly.
--At reunification.
 The child’s foster care provider:
--At or prior to each placement.
--Quarterly.
15

DHHS Policy Quarterly Adoption Progress Reports.
ADM 330
Adoption workers must submit written quarterly progress reports
using the DHS-614, Quarterly Adoption Progress Report. The
adoption worker must have at least one face-to-face contact
with the child during each quarter prior to the adoption
supervision period for the purpose of completing the DHS-614.
The child adoption assessment may serve as the initial quarterly
report if it is completed within the required quarterly reporting
period and attached to the DHS-614 form.
Note: When the child adoption assessment is used as the initial
quarterly report, the next quarterly report is due 90 calendar
days from completion of the child adoption assessment. When
the child adoption assessment is not completed within the initial
required quarterly reporting period, the DHS-614 is due 90
calendar days from case acceptance or 90 days after the order
terminating parental rights is signed, whichever is later.

The second was in response to Special Investigation 2020C0221019 where there
were additional findings a Family Team Meeting (FTM) for the Initial Service Plan

FOM 722-06B Family Team Meetings: Types and Timeframes. The agency

The third was in response to Special Investigation 2021C0221019 where a

without notice or the right to a Foster Care Review Board (FCRB) appeal; the
agency violated the foster parent’s Foster Parent Bill of Rights; the foster child was
returned to her father’s care despite his pending criminal charges, the foster child’s

provided written notice of the court proceedings; the agency did not include the
foster parent in case planning or ensure that their input and written statements were
provided to the court; the agency initiated special investigations in January 2020 and
September 2020, in which the findings were “bogus”; the agency has cancelled
numerous visits and now refuses to complete the annual licensing inspection
because the foster parent refused to sign the corrective action plan (CAP) for a
special investigation; during COVID-19 closures, the agency made the foster parent
transport the foster child to visits; and the agency failed to respond to the foster
parent’s Freedom of Information Act (FOIA) requests. The agency was found in non-
compliance for DHHS Policy FOM 722-10 Court Hearing Notification Requirements
as the agency did not notify the foster parent about all court hearings. The agency
developed a corrective action plan that was appropriate and implemented as verified
with a random review of case files during this audit.
